description.narrative: Major oil spills heavily contaminate marine shorelines, causing severe localised ecological damage to the near-shore community. Theharmful effects of oil spill on the environment are many. Oil destroys plants and animals in the estuarine zone. It settles on beaches and kills organisms and marine animals like fishes, crabs and other crustaceans. Oil endangers fish hatcheries in coastal watersand as well contaminates the flesh of commercially valuable fish. Oil poisons algae, disrupts major food chains and decreases the yield of edible crustaceans. It also coats birds, impairing their flight or reducing the insulative property of their feathers, thus making the birds more vulnerable to cold. Oil on water surface also interferes with gaseous interchange at the sea surface and dissolved oxygen levels will thereby be lowered. This will in no doubt reduce the life span of marine animals. Micro-organisms also degrade petroleum hydrocarbons after spillage In a bid to clean oil spills by the use of oil dispersants, serious toxic effects will be exerted on plankton thereby poisoning marine animals. This can further lead to food poisoning and loss of lives. Another effect of oil slicks is loss of economic resources to the government. When spilled, oil is not quickly recovered. It will be dispersed by the combined action of tides, wind and current. The oil will therefore spread into thin films, dissolve in water and undergo photochemicaloxidation, which will lead to its decomposition. On the Nigerian Coastal environment, large areas of the mangrove ecosystem have been destroyed. Oil spill has also destroyed farmlands, polluted ground and drinkable water and caused drawbacks in fishing off the coastal waters. Oil exploration activities and spills have resulted in the pollution of rivers, streams, ponds and waterways and a threat to the peoples source of livelihood, especially women and girls. There have been continuous regional crises in the Niger Delta area as a result of oil spill pollution of the coastal ecosystem.

participating-org.narrative:
Kebetkache Women Development and Resource Center is a Nigerian non-governmental organisation which vision is a gender sensitive society where women human rights are recognised, accepted and enforced.
Kebetkache applies a holistic approach to the understanding of women rights, which resulted in four overlapping thematic areas/strategic priorities for action: - Women's human rights - ConflictManagement and Peacebuilding - Democracy and Governance - Environment
Its objectives are - to promote gender equality and the advancement of women through human rights awareness - to faciliate women's role in conflict prevention - to counsel and provide information on women's reproductive health and HIV/AIDS - to promote democratic principles - to increase and ensure adequate knowledge on women and environment - to foster sustainable development through economic empowerment of women and youths

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security

description.narrative: Communities innovate and implement locally owned solutions for climate adaptation and resilience, with recognition of the specific needs and aspirations of women, men and youth.
CBOs and NGO's resourced to innovate and implement locally owned solutions, recognizing specific needs and aspirations of women, men and youth

CBOs, producer organisations, NGO and other civil society actors with strengthened capacities to advocate and to increase people's voice in decisions on policies regarding agriculture production systems, land scape management and market systems
local communities, CBOs and small holder organisations that promote innovative locally owned solutions, recognizing and promoting gender equality and women and youth leadership
